stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the platforming layout and geometry for a new ice level (Course 13), fixing bugs and iterating on the design live on N64 hardware. The second half of the stream was dedicated to Kaze hosting and providing live commentary for the F3 (Fan Game Free-for-all) 2024 event.

development_findings.summary: The project is nearing completion, with work focused on Course 13. Only two levels remain to be built after the current one is finished.
development_findings.quote: I hope I can finish this level in the next month or so and then it's just two levels missing.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has a highly efficient workflow that allows him to instantly test the game on original N64 hardware, enabling rapid iteration and hardware-specific bug fixing.
development_findings.quote: All I have to do to test this on the N64 is hit this button here... And now we are on the real N64. It's as shrimpless as that.

development_findings.summary: A camera bug on N64, where the frame buffer doesn't clear in large areas, is being temporarily mitigated by shrinking the level geometry, though a proper engine fix may be needed.
development_findings.quote: I think this level is a little too big and that's why the camera does this... I might have to invent a solution to that problem.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has discovered that some of the original Mario 64 engine's optimizations were inefficient and actually slowed the game down, which he has since corrected in his project.
development_findings.quote: What if I made a video titled How Nintendo's optimizations in Mario 64 made the game run worse.

development_findings.summary: The project pushes the N64's technical limits, featuring optional anti-aliasing and achieving infinite render distance in certain levels while maintaining high performance.
development_findings.quote: This level has infinite drawing distance even on 64. No, by the way. It's still at 60 FPS sometimes.

development_findings.summary: Due to the size constraints of an N64 cartridge (under 64MB), the team uses MIDI for the soundtrack, as compressed audio formats like Opus would still be too large for the entire OST.
development_findings.quote: My problem with OPPO's is that I can't put my entire hex on it... So media is just kind of a better option right now.

development_findings.summary: Kaze strategically embeds project updates and level previews within technical videos to ensure the community sees progress without creating standalone 'spoiler' videos that get low viewership.
development_findings.quote: When I make your previews, people don't want to watch those... But at the same time, I have to let people know that I'm still making progress on the hack.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes ROM hacks have more creative freedom than commercial games because they are not driven by sales, which often leads to blander, safer designs in mainstream titles.
context_findings.quote: When you have to sell well, you have to make something somewhat bland. I think maybe that is why you are looking forward to ROM hack a little more.

context_findings.summary: Kaze strongly opposes the idea of developing fan games in secret out of fear of C&Ds, arguing it's a form of self-censorship and that the risk is overstated.
context_findings.quote: If you make a fan game and you shut up about it and you don't show anyone, you CND'd yourself. Why are you doing Nintendo's job for them?

context_findings.summary: Kaze's artistic philosophy prioritizes creating a specific feeling for the player over adhering to formal art principles, which he believes are for critics, not audiences.
context_findings.quote: You don't want to operate on principles because if you operate on principles, you make art for critics, you don't make art for the sake of it being experienced.

context_findings.summary: To avoid legal issues, Kaze will not sell cartridges of the game but plans to design and sell a custom box and booklet for fans to purchase.
context_findings.quote: I am not allowed to sell real cartridges... But what I am planning to do is make a box and a book inlet without any Nintendo references to it and put that out so you can at least get the box as a souvenir.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and his wife, Zeina, recently had a daughter named Reyna. Zeina's mother is staying with them to help.
context_findings.quote: Yes, the baby came out five days ago.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is consciously against leveraging his personal life, such as his newborn child, for stream content, viewing it as narcissistic.
context_findings.quote: Assuming people care about that reeks of influence on narcissism and I don't like it.

biobak.summary: Biobak designed the concept and model for the updated 'fuzzy' enemies, which now wear protective gear.
biobak.quote: This was Biobak's idea and Biobak made the model. They're now wearing protective gear.

biobak.summary: Kaze acknowledges Biobak's artistic talent, suggesting a viewer might be praising Biobak's color palette choices more than his own.

zeina.summary: Zeina, the project's animator and Kaze's wife, is currently caring for their newborn daughter with help from her mother. She remains active in the stream chat.
zeina.quote: She is currently upstairs with Zeina's mom.

key_stories.title: Refining Platforming in the Ice Level
key_stories.summary: During the design of Course 13, Kaze identified an awkward wall-kicking section. He play-tested it, diagnosed the geometric issue, and adjusted the level on-the-fly to improve the player experience.
key_stories.challenge: A platforming section in the new ice level felt awkward and unnecessarily difficult due to the geometry of the walls used for wall kicks.
key_stories.process: After identifying the issue through play-testing, Kaze immediately opened the level in his modeling software and iteratively adjusted the platforms and walls live on stream.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze adjusted the level geometry to make the walls parallel and provided a longer runway for a triple jump, resulting in a more intuitive and fun platforming challenge.
key_stories.key_quote: These ones should probably be a little more parallel to each other. Because the wall kicks are otherwise a bit awkward.

key_stories.title: Camera Bug Mitigation
key_stories.summary: While testing on N64 hardware, Kaze encountered a major camera bug. He diagnosed it as being caused by the level's large size and implemented a pragmatic, immediate fix by redesigning the area to be more compact.
key_stories.challenge: A severe camera bug was occurring on real N64 hardware where the screen would not clear properly, creating a messy visual artifact.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified that the bug was tied to the large size of the level area. He decided to mitigate the problem by bringing the level's geometry closer together rather than attempting a complex engine-level fix at that moment.
key_stories.outcome: The immediate issue was resolved by shrinking the level's boundaries, preventing the bug from triggering. This indicates a potential need for a more robust, engine-level fix for large-scale environments in the future.
key_stories.key_quote: I think this level is a little too big and that's why the camera does this. It usually does that when you have a really big area.

key_stories.title: Philosophy on Public Fan Game Development
key_stories.summary: Kaze vocally challenged the prevailing fear-based wisdom of keeping fan games secret. He argued that this approach is self-defeating and that open development is more beneficial for creators and the community.
key_stories.challenge: The common wisdom in the fan game community is to maintain secrecy to avoid cease and desist orders from companies like Nintendo.
key_stories.process: Kaze directly addressed the community's fear during his stream, blaming a specific (unnamed) YouTuber for popularizing the idea. He used the F3 event, which has run for years without legal trouble, as a counter-example.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze actively uses his platform to advocate for open development, continuing to stream his progress and host events like F3 to promote other fan games, believing the benefits of community and marketing outweigh the risks.
key_stories.key_quote: If you make a fan game and you shut the fuck up about it... you CND'd yourself. Why are you doing Nintendo's job for them?
